item.title: Relooted Review - Restoring Pride & Ownership To African Art History
item.content:encoded:
On the surface, Relooted first appeared to be a very intriguing game to be introduced to the industry, solely based on its overarching narrative. Since its reveal during the Day of the Devs showcase last year, there have been increased yet negative conversations regarding the controversial subject matter of cultural repatriation, rooted in misinformation and racism.

As such, one was quite cautious, maybe concerned about how nuanced developer Nyamakop will present its story and how it approached tackling this conversation, one that is still ongoing today. After hours of playtime, what it did was leave one feeling frustrated while raising some important questions regarding preservation and the future of modern museums regarding African art repatriation.

Pulling Off Africa's Biggest Heist Of The Century

Nyamakop's 2D side-scrolling puzzle platformer, Relooted, is set in a semi-futuristic city of Johannesburg, South Africa, where we find the game's protagonist, Nomali, embarking on a dangerous mission to rescue her younger brother, Trevor. What follows is Nomali being convinced by her art historian grandmother, Professor Grace, to form a ragtag group of vigilante thieves in a high-stakes mission to reclaim stolen artifacts from the African continent and beyond in an effort to return them home.

Within the context of Relooted in the 21st century, the Transatlantic Returns Treaty has been put into power, operating as an intermediary body to ensure that African artifacts will be safely returned to their place of origin. As expected, there is one major caveat, largely due to some interesting phrasing, that this is only applicable to cultural artifacts that are being publicly displayed in museums globally.

As such, some Western museums have opted to quietly remove the artifacts in question and place them in secure vaults, while private collectors have continued to keep theirs behind locked doors in private collections. Sure, those museums aren't committing anything illegal, but morally, it's quite a heinous thing to do if one isn't planning on returning them.

This is where Nomali, Trevor, and their team come into play, as they've been tasked to "bypass" the Transatlantic Returns Treaty by acting outside the law and reclaiming those artifacts. From the many great heist films, like The Thomas Crown Affair, The Italian Job, the Ocean's trilogy, and Inception as examples, planning a heist looks almost near effortless with careful planning, reconnaissance work, and exceptional team building by using every member's strengths to their advantage.

In the case of Relooted, the team Nomali builds are not hardened criminals nor have criminal backgrounds, but are skilled in their respective areas of expertise, which adds a shade of unpredictability that gives Relooted that thrilling charm. As the game progressed, more members were added, but with these additions came a greater risk of carelessness, overexposure, and failure that jeopardized their plans, team morale, and overall mission of returning priceless cultural artifacts to their native homelands.

Reclaiming Africa's Cultural History

Relooted looks and plays like a well-designed side-scrolling platforming game, but due to the immense amount of research into the game's development lies a game with plenty of heart, soul, and reverence. Relooted features 70 cultural artifacts from the African continent and a few from other cultures outside Africa.

According to a Shacknews interview with Nyamakop's Creative Director Ben Myers, the team employed full-time researchers who assisted and advised the development team with deciding which historical and cultural artifacts would be included in-game. "Not a lot of people realize the scale of African artifacts that aren't in Africa," and as such, for the developers, "a lot of the research was finding the most interesting stories, trying to find artifacts that had huge cultural [or] spiritual importance to the people they were taken from."

Within the context of Relooted, Nomali's art historian grandmother mentions that any and all African artifacts that are returned under the Transatlantic Returns Treaty are granted once a deal is brokered. However, much like in real life, where certain bodies and countries just outright decline to return these historical and cultural African artifacts back to their place of origin, the same situation is being played out in-game.

It has been publicly documented within the media over the last few decades that many African countries have pleaded with museums, private bodies, and organizations to return stolen artifacts to Africa. An example was 39 pieces that were returned to the Ugandan government by the University of Cambridge in 2024; however, the condition was that they were loaned back to the government for a three-year period, which can be extended, according to a news report from CBS News.

Similarly, Germany has promised to return 1,130 artifacts to Nigeria in 2022, with 22 Benin Bronzes already back in the country, based on reporting from the Associated Press. Sadly, not all requests have been approved, as in 2018, the Dapper Foundation has stalled talks to return the Bangwa Queen, which is featured in Relooted, and is still being held in France despite requests for it to be returned to Cameroon.

These cultural pieces still hold great religious significance in their respective countries in today's modern times, yet despite being looted as rewards for the violence invoked across the continent, the request for them to be returned is being denied on the basis that they best belong in the gilded halls of museums around the world. Relooted greatly emphasizes the need for increased dialogue surrounding cultural repatriation by placing a lot of care, dedication, and great detail into highlighting and restoring the historical significance of these artifacts.

Not only are the artifacts intricately recreated by talented 3D artists, but each artifact has well-researched descriptions and is accurately pronounced in the dialogue. "And then we also had a woman who produced our pronunciation guide to make sure the way the artifacts and ethnicities are pronounced is correct and accurate, too,” Myers explained in the Shacknews interview.

Error Controls In The Planning Phase

Relooted has many tremendous components to love and appreciate, especially given the great level of detail that went into the research and development of the game. While Relooted offers a new, fresh, and nuanced experience that one has never seen in the industry to date, the game is held back by some technical and creative issues that were annoying or confusing at times.

A combination of controller issues, gameplay bugs relating to the parkour movement and wall-jumping, and game crashes were the most prevalent technical issues that had one forcibly close the game before relaunching. Sadly, this meant having to backtrack on progress, as the auto-save feature didn't kick in to advance the game and its narrative.

Dealing with controller issues was annoying at times, as some incidents were isolated from other issues. However, it becomes frustrating when it snowballs with other problems, resulting in lost gameplay time and important saved progress if the auto-save wasn't triggered.

The game's platforming was quite an arduous experience, especially in certain locations like the House of Horrors and the Shiny Place heist locations, as timed jumps and speed boosts felt like they were on a delay or couldn't clear gaps with free-running and jumping distance. There were some hilarious ones to boot, like during the Maiden Voyage training session, where, during the Ndedi training session, smashing into a window left one in a glitched state and suspended mid-air, which surely was added to the "Funny Screenshot Moments" folder.

As an addendum, one noticed the disconnect between the planning phase and the heist itself, as many of the questions raised and inquiries asked didn't correspond to the plans that eventually unfolded in the subsequent heist mission, other than finding the artifacts and marking a path to the exit. It is certain that some technical issues are likely to be patched in the coming weeks; what could be slightly improved on is the disjointed character interactions and dialogue options during gameplay.

Some of the performances didn't feel compelling enough to care about certain characters, and there wasn't enough natural or organic chemistry where actors would play off of each other. This wasn't the case in a handful of the cutscenes, naturally, as the interactions were more convincing and well-performed, but the gameplay performances left more to be desired, which is not the fault of the actors but possibly the voice direction that was given.

Relooted Review | Final Thoughts

Undoubtedly, Relooted is a game unlike anything we've seen in today's gaming landscape, which is certainly needed. As a heist sidescrolling platformer, it checks most of the boxes, providing a decent platforming experience, albeit with some technical issues hindering it.

Where it shines the brightest is that it serves as a historical reminder of the continual aftermath of colonialism by illustrating the broad scale of the violent plundering of cultural artifacts by its oppressors. While some have made their way back home, there are still thousands of artifacts that are being withheld by museums, private collections, and other institutions.

In the end, the game recontextualizes the "treasure hunter" trope we see all too often by giving us, the players, the power to do the right thing in reclaiming artifacts and returning them home. This may be some kind of dream come true, but maybe, just maybe, getting to make history by writing a new chapter illustrating that taking back what belongs to them is the right and honorable thing to do.

Relooted was reviewed on PC via Steam, with a copy provided by the publisher over the course of 20 hours - all screenshots were taken during the review.

item.title: Crisol: Theater of Idols Review - Praise the Sun
item.content:encoded:
Crisol: Theater of Idols is, at the very least, an aptly-named game. It really does feel like a theater of idols; in fact, it feels like a theater that pays tribute to two idols in particular, namely BioShock and Resident Evil Village.

The DNA of both games can be found everywhere in developer Vermila Studios and publisher Blumhouse Games' horror shooter. Whether it's the gloomy, glitzy post-disaster setting of Tormentosa, a suspiciously familiar weapon upgrade system, or structural similarities that are hard to ignore, there's no denying the connections.

Of course, it's one thing to pay tribute to your idols and quite another to transcend those influences in order to create something truly original. Crisol: Theater of Idols knows what it likes, but it can't quite find a way to translate those heady origins into something new and compelling.

Crisol: Theater of Idols Is Atmospheric, but Uninvolving

Crisol tells the story of Gabriel, a religious soldier sent to the island of Tormentosa on a holy mission. In true BioShock fashion, Gabriel awakens on the coast of Tormentosa at the outset of his quest and journeys inland, encountering horrors aplenty as he goes.

It's clear that Crisol wants religion and dogma to be the central pillars of its narrative, but it lacks the courage to say anything meaningful about its subject matter. 

What unfolds is not a tale of zealotry and the lengths to which religion will go to subjugate its victims; rather, it's a histrionic, uneven story that takes some pretty egregious logical leaps in attempting to deliver shocking twists.

I don't want to spoil anything, but I found Crisol: Theater of Idols' narrative to be equal parts uninvolving and baffling. Many of its key mysteries felt unresolved, and the conclusions of those that did receive some sort of closure felt unsatisfying and weak.

The problem lies chiefly with characters. Gabriel is about as stock a protagonist as you could hope to find, and his radio support companion Mediodia is intensely, desperately annoying (not to mention horribly animated).

Unfortunately, there aren't many other major characters to get to know; the enemies Gabriel comes across are generally stock characters indebted to their key influences. One major villain even directly paraphrases BioShock during a climactic moment, and it feels like a cheap reference rather than a sly wink.

It's a shame, because the atmosphere on display can be very effective indeed. The sound design here is excellent, capturing the feel of an abandoned city and its labyrinthine horrors perfectly.

When the moon hits a ramshackle dock or a glittering carnival just right, Crisol: Theater of Idols threatens to become immersive, but knowing there's another lame narrative twist around the corner derails that sense of tension.

Not only that, but Crisol is in deep with the yellow paint mob. Its largely linear environments are covered in these patronizing, obvious directional signals, and it lessens immersion even further. Who's painting the entrances of these tunnels? Who knows Gabriel's journey better than he does?

Combat In Crisol: Theater of Idols Struggles With Repetition

During Crisol's opening moments, Gabriel comes face-to-face with a creepy porcelain mannequin enemy, which wrenches itself off the wall and rushes him with nary a change of its painted expression.

It's a very effective opener, and the ways in which Gabriel can dismember the creature and even behead it without making a dent set up an adaptable, worryingly durable foe that will take smarts and perseverance to overcome.

Sadly, this is another area in which Crisol disappoints. These mannequins will form the vast bulk of the enemies you'll face throughout a roughly 10-12-hour playthrough; I reckon about 90% of the enemy encounters are made up solely of these guys.

Over the course of my time with Crisol, I counted four distinct enemy types. One, a sort of goblin creature that crawls between paintings, isn't really a combat encounter; it and its friends infinitely respawn, meaning it's much more worth your time to sprint to your goal rather than engage the monster.

The best survival horror games constantly wrong-foot you with new enemy types and changes to existing enemies, meaning you're never quite able to relax. Crisol absolutely fails on this front; its encounters are so repetitive that they're almost comforting.

Your weapons themselves feel...fine. It's a pretty bog-standard lineup - think pistol, shotgun, rifle - but bullets land with a satisfying enough thud. That's only half of the equation, though, and when enemies are this boring to fight, even Doom Eternal's gunplay wouldn't suffice.

There's Simply No Scarcity in Crisol: Theater of Idols

I bring up survival horror because Crisol: Theater of Idols explicitly bills itself as such, and judged on these terms, it's an abject failure.

Crisol revolves around a rather neat little mechanic whereby blood serves as ammunition, so if you want to keep yourself stocked up, you'll have to sacrifice health to do so.

Blood can be recovered by draining animals (and, sometimes, humans) throughout your environment, as well as by using consumable syringes. As such, Crisol clearly wants you to constantly be asking whether it's worth draining that last scrap of health to give yourself a fighting chance in a battle.

It's unfortunate, then, that Crisol suffers from an almost total lack of scarcity. There was not a single point during my playthrough when I struggled for resources. I was awash with blood, drowning in corpses, carrying a bag bulging with syringes.

Ironically enough for a horror game, Crisol seems terrified of alienating you or frustrating you, so its levels are absolutely chock-full of health pickups. I was constantly ignoring syringes or using them with 95% of my health remaining just so I could pick up more.

Without scarcity, a survival horror game can no longer deliver on dread. If you're constantly well-prepared for whatever's coming around the next corner, then it won't surprise you or terrify you.

Combined with the terminal lack of enemy variety, any chance that Crisol can provide a tense or scary experience is gone.

The problem, though, is this: if Crisol doesn't work as a survival horror shooter, and its enemies are nowhere near varied enough for a serviceable action-horror game, then what, exactly, do we have before us?

Crisol: Theater of Idols - Final Thoughts

It pains me to say it, given the obvious ambition on display, but Crisol: Theater of Idols just...doesn't work.

Its survival horror elements are undone by a total lack of scarcity, thus making resource management a complete non-issue, and its enemy encounters are stultifyingly repetitive, thus kneecapping any chance of high-octane and exciting combat.

Crisol just feels like it keeps getting in its own way. Its atmosphere is moody and compelling, but undone by overbearing yellow paint guidance. Its guns feel weighty, but the enemies you'll use them on are too boring to provide catharsis.

BioShock worked because it had a message, and Resident Evil Village worked because it constantly kept you guessing. Crisol does neither, and as such, it's a safe skip, even if you love its influences.

Crisol: Theater of Idols was reviewed on PC with a copy provided by the developer over the course of 12 hours of gameplay. All screenshots were taken during the process of review.

item.title: G.I. Joe Snake Eyes Game Dev Reportedly Shut Down, but Game Is Still Coming
item.content:encoded:
A new report has emerged which claims that Hasbro has closed down Atomic Arcade, the developer of the company's upcoming G.I. Joe Snake Eyes game, but that the game itself is still in the works.

As spotted by Wccftech, a LinkedIn post by former Atomic Arcade software engineer Dominic Braun makes reference to "Hasbro's and Wizards of the Coast's decision to close Atomic Arcade", which Braun says means there are now "a lot of really great people" looking for work.

A Hasbro representative subsequently told Wccftech that the G.I. Joe Snake Eyes game itself is "not canceled", and that Hasbro and Wizards of the Coast are "currently taking time to evaluate the path forward for the game".

The two companies say that no decisions about the game's future have yet been "finalized", but that updates will be provided "as soon as [they're] able".

This G.I. Joe game may or may not be the same one that was first announced all the way back in 2021, but if it is, it's an ignominious end for a studio that's been working on the game for at least the last five years.

Unfortunately, Atomic Arcade isn't the first studio to be shut down in the last few months. Back in January, Ubisoft closed down its Halifax wing just weeks after it unionized, and other developers to have met with the axe recently include Squid Game: Unleashed studio Boss Fight and Metal: Hellsinger outfit The Outsiders.

If the G.I. Joe Snake Eyes game has indeed avoided cancellation, it's lucky to have done so; high-profile projects like MMO Ashes of Creation (reportedly, at least) and Ubisoft's Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time remake haven't been so fortunate.

We'll have to wait and see what happens to the G.I. Joe Snake Eyes game in the future, but presumably, Hasbro and Wizards of the Coast will make an announcement relating to it soon. Stay tuned for more.
